question: That play, my friends, sums up the Redskins' running game all day long. Now Washington calls their last time out.
answer: Hey, the Dolphins do this as good as anybody. See, in a four, three, two, two, you got the guards... boom!... Plugging up the middle, then the corners... boom and

question: Third and twenty-two, but forget the first down with eight seconds showing and the Skins down by a touchdown.
answer: Could be the last play.

question: Could be the last play of the season if the players go out.
answer: Take it all in, people. This could be it for 2,000. It's all about money, folks. More money, of course and ain't it always? The shame of it is the big losers are you out there, the fans.

question: Did they win or lose?! That has the distinct tonal quality of a loss. Nice medicine for a loss. Keeps us calm. Makes us not so sad. Keeps us on an even keel. Gives us some perspective, doesn't it? And we'll save the winning medicine for next Sunday, won't we?
answer: If you keep talking to me like I'm a five- year-old, I'm going to hurt you.

question: Sounds exciting. We'll want to talk to coach now, won't we?
answer: What the fuck was that?! Bullshit he slipped! He could have scored! You god damn wimp! You're fired! Get out! Get out! Get out!

question: Better? It always makes you feel better when you fire someone, we know it does, don't we? Yes...
answer: Get me Jimmy McGinty. Get him here. Tonight.

question: ... Six phone lines with internet access on two
answer: We thought we would skip special teams for the moment.

question: Except for a kicker. We definitely need a kicker. A place kicker over a punter.
answer: The thinking being that if we lose the toss, we have to be able to at least kick off.

question: Oh shit! No!
answer: Hi, I'm Danny.

question: Shane.
answer: Thank's, Coach!

question: Annabelle Farrell, head Redskinette.
answer: Excuse me?

question: I'm in charge. Of the Redskinettes. The cheerleaders?
answer: Oh yeah, hi.

question: I've been watching you. You look good. You look strong. Good quick release. Smart. You read defenses quickly. You're gonna do great.
answer: Hey... thanks.

question: I saw your second concussion. The one
answer: I guess so.

question: If there's anything you need, let me know. And I mean anything, okay? You understand?
answer: Sure. I understand.

question: They put you up at the Hilton?
answer: Yeah.

question: Hey, you can't park there.
answer: Look, I don't want any trouble.

question: You don't want any trouble?! You're taking my job away, but you don't want any trouble? He doesn't want any trouble, but he puts this piece of shit in a no parking zone.
answer: Okay. I'll move it.

question: No, it's not. That's your ride, ain't it?
answer: My windshield! You crazy motherfucker!

question: Move his car back.
answer: My car! No! Stop! Come on, help me, god damn it! You are gonna pay for this.

question: Let's do that.
answer: Praise the Lord, Shane.

question: Yeah. Sure.
answer: Walt Cochran. Offensive tackle. Shane, will you witness with me?

question: Will I what?
answer: Will you witness with me? For this upcoming practice.

question: Now?
answer: Praise the Lord for giving us a way to eliminate, Shane. Why not talk to Him in the midst of performing his gift? Heavenly Father, thank you for allowing us to pee the poisons from our systems. Please help us in today's practice to be strong and...

question: Your Honor, or Judge is fine. I played at Harvard. But I played in the days when you went both ways. Offense and defense. When players were really tough. And where did you play college ball... I'm sorry, what was your name again?
answer: Smith. Ray Smith. I played at a junior college nobody ever heard of. What position did you play on defense, Judge?

question: Middle linebacker.
answer: Yeah, big fellow like you, that's what I would have guessed.

question: It was a different game in those days. Raw. Powerful. No tricks, like today.
answer: You know, maybe you can show me some of your technique, Your Honor. Maybe you can show me some of that toughness.

question: McGinty, I mean.
answer: I was kind of thinking the same thing.

question: My theory is he came out of retirement to see if he could win with losers. Oh, shit. I'm sorry. I didn't mean...
answer: Hey, it's okay. I've been called worse.

question: Like after that Sugar Bowl game? I guess you could survive anything after that.
answer: Sometimes I feel like everybody in the world saw that game. Like I could go to India and some little guy would run up to me and say, 'Boy, did you suck in So, how come you're such a fan?

question: My dad. He's a huge Redskin fan. For years. He's in his twenty-ninth year at the Senate Office Building. As a guard, not a senator. The only thing that keeps him going he says, is me and the Redskins. That's where I get it. My fan-ness. Are you scared?
answer: Scared? Well... yes. Absolutely.

question: It's okay. Anybody would be. But you're good. And you'll do good.
answer: Well, thank you. Look, I gotta study the play book tonight. So... I'll see you.

question: Break a leg tomorrow.
answer: What?!

question: ... ultimately, it's a pain thing, you know? I mean, it's Darwinian, the survival of the numbest. Whoever can take the pain most, gets the largest contract. It's sick.
answer: I don't know how you do it. I hate pain. Pain is a no no as far as I'm concerned.

question: I'm glad that you are concerned.
answer: Hey, are you alright? I'll take you up to your room, if you like.

question: I would like. Here's home.
answer: A friend of mine is going to join us, okay?

question: Why did you do that?
answer: You were about to be rolled.

question: That's what I was hoping.
answer: They work the bar downstairs looking for drunk Redskins.

question: I guess they found one.
answer: Don't feel so bad. It's a rookie mistake.

question: Here. Take this.
answer: What is it?

question: It's for the pain. Take it. It's only a little bit illegal.
answer: Oh, God. I've got to go to the bathroom. It's far away, isn't it?

question: I'll help. We'll just take our time. Kidneys.
answer: Oh, man. My hair hurts.

question: You took a hell of a beating. The martinis didn't help, either. Don't be afraid if you've got blood in your urine. That's normal.
answer: Did you undress me?

question: Yes.
answer: And you... slept here with me?

question: Yes.
answer: Did we... ?

question: Are you kidding? You were catatonic.
answer: No blood.

question: Good. Back to bed.
answer: May I ask you a personal question? Do you do this for all Redskin quarterbacks?

question: Of course not.
answer: Then why me?

question: I don't know. I guess I can't resist a man who can take a hit.
answer: I can't take a hit!

question: Shhh. It's all in your head. Now, get some sleep. You're the golden boy in the press this morning. 'Falco scores big.' Well... not really. Hey, a lot of the regular players are starting to cross the picket line.
answer: Redskins?

question: It doesn't say. Where are you going?
answer: McGinty called a dinner meeting with the whole team. Thank you. Thanks for... everything. You saved my life.

question: No. Probably just your wallet and your watch.
answer: And that pill, that sure worked.

question: You're basic double D Vicodin. But be careful
answer: Well...

question: Hi. Come in.
answer: No. We don't travel with the team. So, here's Tylenol with codeine, regular Vicodins, the magic bullet one that I gave you before, and a couple of Darvons if you actually break something. Pop 'em in the ambulance.

question: Wow. Thanks.
answer: I'll be watching on TV. The Giants got back three of their four defensive linemen.

question: Yeah. I know.
answer: What can I say? Go from the shotgun and scramble your ass off.

question: Are you hurt?
answer: No. Not really.

question: You're getting used to being slapped around. That's a good sign. Would you like to come in and make love?
answer: Yes. No. I'm here because ... I don't want to be alone.

question: Most of the world feels that way. You don't have to be embarrassed about it.
answer: But to tell you the truth... I'm kind of scared of you.

question: I won't hurt you. That shoulder is going to need special handling.
answer: You know what hurts

question: I can't imagine.
answer: Their defensive end punched me in the mouth. Seriously. It's killing me. ... after that game, after being beaten that badly in front of the whole country, after humiliating myself, my team, my school, my family, I mean -- did you know that I set two Sugar Bowl records?! I was sacked eleven times! I threw six interceptions!

question: Okay. Calm down.
answer: Anyway, after that, I could never seem to adjust in the pros. I was too scared. I lost my balls.

question: Well, they're back.
answer: You know what I mean. My nerve. I lost the edge you need to play this game.

question: I don't believe that. I don't think it just goes away. It was only one bad day, Shane. Everybody has those.
answer: No. Somehow, I convinced myself that I couldn't ever win the big game. I got so down, that I was afraid to be playing when a game was on the line. I was afraid to screw up. That's the sure sign of a loser. From there, it wasn't very far to thinking that I'll never win, that I didn't deserve to win at anything. Including love.

question: What's this?
answer: This is a visit.

question: A visit. Who let you in?
answer: I used to nail one of the housekeepers.

question: Lucky girl.
answer: You know who these guys are, don't you?

question: Dallas Cowboys. Howdy.
answer: You'll be seeing a lot of these guys tomorrow.

question: What do you want?
answer: Who, me? Not much. But these boys wanted a little head start on you.

question: I'm flattered that you actually think we have a chance to win.
answer: It can be a game of luck. And under no circumstances can we allow a scab team to go three and O. Especially against the Dallas Cowboys. It's just not good for the

question: Is the union behind this 'visit'?
answer: I can't really say, Shane. By the way, have you ever tried throwing a football with bruised ribs? The pain makes it damn near impossible. And one other thing The sad fact is she won't give me the time of day. But you can't have everything I want. I can't let that happen. So, you gotta stop seeing her. Just on principle. Let me hear you say it. Come on. You can do it.

question: I won't go out with her
answer: Good. Gentlemen? Hey, have a great game!
